title: What are some criticisms of Stoic philosophy? - Quora

response.answer_text: Just the criticisms of Stoicism as it actually is, or also the ones of Stoicism as it’s often seen (i.e. based on misinterpretation)? Either might be useful, so I’ll look at both. Legitimate Criticisms (based on a correct understanding of Stoicism) The claim that a person can achieve eudaimonia exclusively through virtue—without any dependence on externals—may or may not be true. Since the Sage is not someone that’s claimed to be common, it’s virtually impossible to verify. Other schools of thought like Peripateticism and Epicureanism included other factors in the pursuit of eudaimonia.Response: various ascetics throughout history (Cynics, Buddhist ascetics, etc) seem to have been perfectly happy with it; granted, this doesn’t take it to the fullest extent (e.g. torture), but it’s something. Regardless, even if our claim isn’t true, training oneself to approach that capability to the extent possible certainly isn’t going to hurt.From the other end of things, permitting the enjoyment of preferred indifferents—simply waiting your turn, as opposed to turning it down altogether, per Enchiridion 15—can be argued to be detrimental to the pursuit of virtue. This would be the challenge from the Cynic perspective, which held askesis, training (asceticism), as a requirement rather than the Stoic approach of simply recommending it from time to time.Response: it’s definitely not as good practice for temperance and fortitude to indulge in preferred indifferents, and we freely admit that Cynicism is, per Epictetus, the shorter path to virtue. However, accepting a pleasure is not equivalent to intemperance, and it is possible to do so without mistaking the nature of the thing (preference, rather than desire).Stoicism’s references to Nature can be ambiguous or difficult to justify. Does Nature refer to nature as we use it today? Then it’s very difficult to draw any morality from it. Does Nature refer to Divine Nature, Logos? Then it works fine if you’re a pantheist in particular or a theist in general, but makes Stoicism reliant on theism. Does Nature refer to the individual’s ideal nature (which is how I interpret it)? That’s broadly workable, but we don’t know that that’s actually what it means.Response: there isn’t a clear-cut answer here, but Stoicism is a philosophy, not a religion, and can therefore be updated in response to challenges. It is no issue for Stoic practice to choose the “ideal nature” interpretation, where the ideal nature of a human includes rationality and altruism.And for a more extreme version of the first point: is virtue relevant to eudaimonia at all? Hedonist philosophies, for instance, would say otherwise. Even Epicureanism, which did see virtue as valuable, used it only as a means to an end (the wise person will be tranquil—the goal being tranquility, not wisdom).Response: many, many examples suggest that virtue provides for more lasting happiness than pleasure. Many hedonists find themselves self-destructing, or at the very least their happiness is fragile (if they lose their pleasures). For virtue, on the other hand, we can point to many examples of happy ascetics—and none that come to mind of those who are both wise in the Stoic sense and unhappy, or at risk of losing their happiness.Virtue ethics in general are impossible to apply to other people. I can say my own conduct is right or wrong, but I can’t say the same of yours. This very point is repeated throughout Stoic texts, like in Enchiridion 45 (“Does someone bathe quickly? Then don’t say he bathes badly, but that he bathes quickly.”).Response: why do we need to judge other people? We can act for the common good without passing judgement, and if correction is needed, we can act with the aim of preventing and correcting harm rather than of punishing erroneous behavior (restorative vs retributive justice—the former generally being far more effective, and the Stoic approach).Misunderstandings Stoicism requires practitioners to be emotionless or to suppress their emotions.Response: Stoic doctrine does not teach us to attack emotions directly, only at that level to moderate them if necessary (i.e. don’t let anger make you hurt someone). Rather, we approach it at the origin, correcting our false judgements so that problematic emotions do not arise and do not need to be suppressed. And this is not emotionlessness—Stoics have no issue with joy, for instance. We merely avoid false judgements, and the resulting passions (fear and anger, for instance, arise from the false belief that externals can be bad).Stoicism is overly masculine or male-centric.Response: “manliness” in the translations is an alternate translation of “virtue”—and that’s just phrasing. Are you claiming that wisdom is a masculine characteristic? That seems doubtful. This is one of those bizarre arguments that implies that men are more rational than women.Stoicism teaches apathy and that its practitioners should accept injustice/not be politically active.Response: Stoicism teaches that we shouldn’t be troubled by externals. It does not teach that we shouldn’t act—in fact, there is an imperative to act in the virtue of Justice. Stoics are required to act for the common good, but to do so in a calm and rational way. And has this not been shown to be more effective historically? MLK, Gandhi, Nelson Mandela—all approached politics with moderation and discipline. Those who took a less restrained approach? Unless outright war was necessary (revolutions), they are historical footnotes, interesting people who didn’t accomplish very much.(I’ve read all three of those from the same person, some Cambridge philosopher who can’t possibly have actually read the texts of the philosophy she’s criticizing, or else she’d know those are all incorrect).

Stoic philosophy has 3 parts: physics, logic and ethics. Crticisms of physics (there are many) may relate to discoveries we have made about our world since Stocism was founded 2,300 years ago, and also that the Ancient Stoics believed in a creator. I am not familiar with critiques of stoic logic - what I know about their logic is that it is pretty reasonable. Criticisms of Stoic ethics may be more interesting for us. Among these: it isn't funit is too hard to practice (for the average human)it is actually impossible (for a human to become a Stoic sage)it doesn't work (Stoic suppositions about emotions are wrong)it is unsatisfactory from an eschatalogical perspective (Christians might say this)Leaving aside both the eschatalogical critique and the lack of fun point, a practicing Stoic might respond: "Yes, it is hard. So what? I am taking responsibility for my feelings and emotions. It's worth the effort. "It may be impossible to fully become a sage, but that doesn't mean we shouldn't try. The benefits of miving in that direction are worth it. "And it does work. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy is empirically proven to work, and it is essentially applied Stoicism."
